Number Recognition.quote: Learning to identify and write numbers 0-9 is the foundation of mathematics.

Counting.quote: One-to-one correspondence: each object is counted exactly once.

Place Value.quote: In 234, 2 represents hundreds, 3 represents tens, and 4 represents ones.

Subtraction.quote: Taking away from a set: If you have 5 cookies and eat 2, you have 3 cookies left.

Multiplication.quote: Repeated addition: 3 ร 4 means adding 3 four times or 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 12.

Division.quote: Sharing equally: 12 รท 3 means dividing 12 items into 3 equal groups.

Fractions.quote: Parts of a whole: 1/4 means one part when something is divided into four equal parts.

Decimals.quote: Extension of place value: 0.1 is one-tenth, 0.01 is one-hundredth.

Money Math.quote: Understanding currency: 100 cents = 1 dollar, making change, counting money.

Time.quote: Reading clocks: 60 minutes = 1 hour, telling time to the nearest minute.

Measurement.quote: Length, weight, capacity: using rulers, scales, and measuring cups.

Geometry Basics.quote: Identifying shapes: circles, squares, triangles, rectangles, and their properties.

Patterns.quote: Recognizing and continuing sequences: 2, 4, 6, 8... what comes next?

Word Problems.quote: Applying math to real situations: If you have 3 bags with 4 marbles each, how many marbles total?

Mental Math.quote: Computing in your head: 10 + 20 = 30 without writing it down.

Estimation.quote: Making reasonable guesses: Rounding 48 to 50 for easier calculation.

Number Lines.quote: Visual representation of numbers and their relationships: locating numbers, counting forward and backward.

Greater Than/Less Than.quote: Comparing numbers: 5 > 3 (five is greater than three), 2 < 7 (two is less than seven).

Even and Odd.quote: Numbers that can/cannot be divided evenly by 2: 2,4,6,8 are even; 1,3,5,7 are odd.

Basic Graphs.quote: Picture graphs, bar graphs: visual representation of data.

Ordinal Numbers.quote: Position or order: first, second, third...

Number Bonds.quote: Part-whole relationships: 10 can be split into 6 and 4.

Calendar Math.quote: Days, weeks, months: 7 days in a week, 12 months in a year.

Basic Statistics.quote: Simple data analysis: most, least, same, different.

Problem Solving.quote: Strategies: draw a picture, make a table, work backward.

Math Facts.quote: Basic number combinations: memorizing addition and multiplication tables.
